column7: What is your highest level of education?
column8: Is your educational background related to STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics)?
column10: In which industry/domain does your company operate (e.g., finance, game development, enterprise software)?
column11: What is the size of your company?
column12: How long have you been working in software development?
column15: What types of projects do you most often work on?
column16: Column
column17: How frequently do you experience interruptions in a typical workday?
column18: What are the most common sources of interruptions in your work?
column19: What are these interruptions usually about?
column20: Who interrupts you most often at work?
column21: How much do interruptions disrupt your focus and workflow? (1 = not disruptive at all, 5 = very disruptive)
column22: How quickly do you switch to handling the new "interrupting " task?
column23: On average, how long does it take you to regain full focus after an interruption?
column24: Do you use any techniques to reduce interruptions (e.g., focus time, “do not disturb” status)?
column25: What methods do you personally use to reduce or manage interruptions during your work? (max. 3)
column26: How effective do you consider these methods to be? (1 = ineffective, 5 = very effective)
column27: How do you rate your productivity in a typical workday? (1 = very low, 5 = very high)
column28: How often do you feel that interruptions negatively affect the quality of your work? (1 = never, 5 - very often)
column29: How satisfied are you with your job overall (job satisfaction)? (1 = very dissatisfied, 5 = very satisfied)
column30: What actions could you take to better manage or reduce unplanned interruptions in your workday? (max 3)
column31: What actions could your team take to better manage or reduce unplanned interruptions in your workday? (max 3)
column32: What actions could your company take to better manage or reduce unplanned interruptions in your workday? (max 3)
column33: Would you be willing to participate in the next stage of the study — an interview?
column34: Please provide an email address where we can contact you regarding an interview.

column30: 1.	Block dedicated focus time on my calendar and mute non-critical notifications during those periods. 	2.	Set clearer expectations with colleagues about my availability and preferred communication channels. 	3.	Prioritize tasks at the start of each day so I can quickly refocus after any unavoidable interruptions
column31: 1.	Establish shared team norms for communication, including when to use chat, email, or meetings. 	2.	Consolidate non-urgent requests into daily or weekly sync points instead of ad-hoc interruptions. 	3.	Improve documentation and knowledge-sharing so fewer urgent “quick questions” arise.
column32: 1.	Promote a company-wide culture that respects focus time and minimizes unnecessary context switching. 	2.	Provide tools or processes that streamline task management and reduce last-minute escalations. 	3.	Align priorities and planning more consistently across departments to prevent unexpected work requests.

column30: Set dedicated focus time blocks with “Do Not Disturb” enabled to minimize spontaneous interruptions during deep-work tasks. Improve daily planning and prioritization, including reserving buffer time for unexpected issues to reduce context-switching. Communicate availability proactively so teammates know when I’m open for questions and when I need uninterrupted time.
column31: 1.	Establish clear communication windows for questions and discussions to avoid constant context switching. 	2.	Improve task planning and backlog refinement to reduce last-minute surprises. 	3.	Use a shared channel or ticketing system for non-urgent requests instead of direct ad-hoc messages.
column32: 1.	Provide guidelines for communication expectations, including response times and “focus time” etiquette. 	2.	Invest in better tooling and automation to reduce manual work and unexpected operational issues. 	3.	Ensure realistic workload and clearer prioritization so teams can focus without frequent unplanned shifts.

column18: I do not experience interruptions. I am a fully remote senior XR tester now, I receive the software build to test every Monday morning via email, and spend 36 hours (6 hours a day) with a XR4 headset on my face testing it on my own, and then every Saturday afternoon I email my feedback directly to the CEO. Again no interruptions.
